title: Lyme Neuroborreliosis
icd10: ** A69.22 (Other neurologic disorders in Lyme disease)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of nervous system involvement by Borrelia burgdorferi infection, including early neuroborreliosis (cranial neuropathy, lymphocytic meningitis, painful radiculopathy/Bannwarth syndrome) and late neuroborreliosis (encephalomyelitis, peripheral neuropathy, encephalopathy). Includes diagnosis with two-tier serologic testing and CSF analysis, treatment with IV ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline, and management of post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome (PTLDS). Excludes non-neurologic Lyme disease (erythema migrans, Lyme arthritis, Lyme carditis) unless as context for neurologic presentation.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: First-tier screening test in two-tier algorithm; sensitivity 70-100% depending on disease stage (lower in early infection <2 weeks); high sensitivity in disseminated/late disease
Essential/Core Labs.target: Positive or equivocal (proceed to Western blot); negative in very early infection does not exclude

Essential/Core Labs.item: Lyme Western blot IgM and IgG (serum) (CPT 86617)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Second-tier confirmatory test; IgM positive if >=2 of 3 bands (23, 39, 41 kDa); IgG positive if >=5 of 10 bands; IgM only reliable within first 4 weeks of illness
Essential/Core Labs.target: IgM: >=2 of 3 bands (early disease). IgG: >=5 of 10 bands (disseminated/late disease). IgM alone unreliable after 4 weeks

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection markers; rule out hematologic mimics; lymphocytosis may be present
Renal function for antibiotic dosing; hepatic function (Lyme hepatitis may coexist); electrolytes
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; document baseline Cr and LFTs

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Inflammatory marker; often elevated in disseminated Lyme disease
Essential/Core Labs.target: May be mildly to moderately elevated

Essential/Core Labs.item: Blood glucose (paired with CSF if LP performed) (CPT 82947)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Modified two-tier testing (MTTT); some labs now use C6 ELISA as first or second tier; may improve sensitivity in early disease
Immunosuppression may alter Lyme disease presentation and serologic response; co-infection consideration in endemic areas
Neurosyphilis in differential (cranial neuropathies, meningitis, radiculopathy); must be excluded
Thyroid dysfunction in differential for fatigue, cognitive complaints, and neuropathy
B12 deficiency neuropathy in differential for peripheral neuropathy presentation
SLE and other autoimmune conditions in differential for cranial neuropathies, meningitis
Neurosarcoidosis in differential (cranial neuropathies, meningitis, radiculopathy)
Diabetic neuropathy in differential if peripheral neuropathy presentation
Co-infection with Babesia microti common in endemic areas (Northeast US); affects clinical presentation and treatment
Co-infection with Anaplasma (human granulocytic anaplasmosis) common in endemic areas; thrombocytopenia, leukopenia suggest co-infection
Tick-borne co-infection screening in endemic areas

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Low sensitivity (10-30%) but high specificity; may be useful in seronegative early disease or when serologic interpretation is unclear
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative (positive confirms B. burgdorferi DNA in CNS)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Transient spirochetemia; low sensitivity; rarely positive in disseminated disease
Emerging biomarker for active neuroborreliosis; elevated in acute neuroborreliosis; declines with treatment; may be useful for early diagnosis and treatment monitoring; not widely available
Autoimmune encephalitis in differential if encephalopathy or psychiatric symptoms
If rapidly progressive neurologic syndrome with atypical features
GBS in differential if ascending weakness or cranial neuropathy pattern
If myelopathy or optic neuritis component raises concern for NMOSD

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out elevated ICP; usually normal or mildly elevated in Lyme meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly elevated (10-20 cm H2O)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis is the hallmark of neuroborreliosis; typically 10-1000 WBC/uL (lymphocyte predominant); distinguishes from bacterial meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC typically 10-1000 cells/uL (lymphocyte predominant >80%); plasma cells may be present (suggestive of Lyme)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Usually normal in Lyme meningitis (distinguishes from bacterial and TB meningitis where glucose is low)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (>60% serum glucose ratio); low glucose suggests bacterial or TB meningitis, NOT Lyme

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Exclude bacterial meningitis in acute presentation

GOLD STANDARD for neuroborreliosis diagnosis; compares CSF:serum antibody ratio to determine intrathecal antibody production; elevated index confirms CNS infection (not just passive diffusion from serum)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Elevated CSF:serum antibody index (>1.0-1.3 depending on lab) confirms intrathecal antibody production = neuroborreliosis

Lumbar Puncture.item: CSF Lyme IgM and IgG antibodies (CPT 86618)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Detect Borrelia-specific antibodies in CSF; must be interpreted alongside serum antibodies (CSF:serum index); isolated CSF positivity without elevated index may represent passive diffusion
Lumbar Puncture.target: Positive CSF Lyme antibodies (interpret with antibody index)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rapid multiplex PCR to exclude viral and bacterial meningitis pathogens; does NOT detect Borrelia
Intrathecal immunoglobulin synthesis; positive in neuroborreliosis; also positive in MS (differential)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Often positive (intrathecal IgG synthesis); not specific

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Leptomeningeal malignancy in differential for chronic meningitis
TB meningitis in differential if chronic lymphocytic meningitis

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24-48h; STAT if altered mental status, focal deficits, or concern for encephalomyelitis
Essential/First-line.target: Cranial nerve enhancement (especially CN VII); leptomeningeal enhancement; white matter lesions (late neuroborreliosis); may be NORMAL in early neuroborreliosis with isolated cranial neuropathy or meningitis

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate in ED if acute neurologic presentation (altered consciousness, focal deficit, papilledema) to rule out mass/hemorrhage before LP
Essential/First-line.target: Usually normal; excludes mass lesion before LP

Extended.timing: If myelopathy symptoms (weakness, sensory level, bladder dysfunction) suggesting Lyme myelitis
Extended.target: Spinal cord T2 hyperintensity; nerve root enhancement (radiculitis); meningeal enhancement

Extended.timing: If peripheral neuropathy or radiculopathy symptoms to characterize pattern and severity
Extended.target: Axonal polyneuropathy (late neuroborreliosis); radiculopathy pattern (early); mononeuritis multiplex (rare)

Extended.timing: Screen for Lyme carditis (AV block) which may coexist with neuroborreliosis; baseline before ceftriaxone
Extended.target: PR prolongation or AV block (Lyme carditis); baseline QTc

Rare/Specialized.timing: If seizures, altered mental status, or encephalopathy
Rare/Specialized.target: Focal or generalized slowing (encephalopathy); epileptiform discharges (rare in Lyme)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If subclinical demyelination suspected (late neuroborreliosis); optic nerve or brainstem involvement
If PR prolongation or AV block on ECG (Lyme carditis workup)
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal or valvular abnormalities; evaluate cardiac function

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line treatment for neuroborreliosis with CNS involvement (meningitis, encephalomyelitis, encephalopathy) and cranial neuropathy with CSF pleocytosis; also for Lyme radiculopathy with CSF abnormalities

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV once daily for 14-28 days (most experts recommend 14-21 days); infuse over 30-60 min; standard duration 14 days for most cases, 21-28 days for late neuroborreliosis or encephalomyelitis

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Cephalosporin anaphylaxis; severe penicillin allergy (cross-reactivity ~1-2%); caution with biliary disease (ceftriaxone can cause biliary sludge/pseudolithiasis)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function (BUN, Cr) weekly; CBC weekly; LFTs; monitor for C. difficile diarrhea; biliary symptoms; IV site assessment

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line for isolated facial palsy WITHOUT CSF pleocytosis or other evidence of CNS involvement; also acceptable for Lyme radiculopathy without meningitis in European practice; IDSA/AAN guidelines support oral doxycycline for cranial neuropathy without meningitis

dosing.instructions: 100 mg PO BID for 14-21 days; take with full glass of water; remain upright 30 min after dosing to prevent esophageal ulceration

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Pregnancy; children <8 years; severe hepatic impairment; concurrent retinoids; esophageal stricture
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: GI tolerance; photosensitivity counseling; LFTs if prolonged course

Acute/Emergent.indication: Alternative parenteral beta-lactam for neuroborreliosis when ceftriaxone is contraindicated (biliary disease) or unavailable; equivalent CNS penetration

doseOptions.orderSentence: Cefotaxime (alternative to ceftriaxone) 2 g q8h IV

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV every 8 hours for 14-28 days
dosing.orderSentence: Cefotaxime (alternative to ceftriaxone) 2 g q8h IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function; CBC; LFTs; C. difficile monitoring

Acute/Emergent.indication: Alternative parenteral antibiotic for neuroborreliosis; effective but less commonly used than ceftriaxone due to q4h dosing requirement; reserved for beta-lactam-tolerant patients when ceftriaxone unavailable

doseOptions.orderSentence: Penicillin G (aqueous crystalline) 18-24 million units/day IV

dosing.instructions: 3-4 million units IV q4h (total 18-24 million units/day) for 14-28 days
dosing.orderSentence: Penicillin G (aqueous crystalline) 18-24 million units/day IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function; serum potassium (high-dose penicillin contains potassium); seizure risk at very high doses

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric adjunctive therapy if bacterial meningitis cannot yet be excluded pending culture results; give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose; discontinue if Lyme meningitis confirmed (no role for steroids in Lyme meningitis)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (if bacterial meningitis not excluded) 0.15 mg/kg q6h x 4 days IV

dosing.instructions: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h for 4 days (discontinue if Lyme meningitis confirmed); administer before or with first antibiotic dose
dosing.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (if bacterial meningitis not excluded) 0.15 mg/kg q6h x 4 days IV

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose; blood pressure; discontinue when Lyme confirmed

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache and pain management in Lyme meningitis; radicular pain

dosing.instructions: 400-600 mg PO q6-8h as needed; max 2400 mg/day; take with food

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment; active GI bleed; aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease; third trimester pregnancy
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: GI symptoms; renal function; blood pressure

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache and pain management; fever reduction; alternative if NSAIDs contraindicated

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 3 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease; active liver failure

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (Lyme radiculopathy; painful radiculoneuritis/Bannwarth syndrome; peripheral neuropathy)

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3d to 300 mg TID; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; dose adjust for CrCl <60

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (Lyme radiculopathy; peripheral neuropathy); alternative to gabapentin

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase to 150 mg BID after 1 wk; max 300 mg BID (600 mg/day); dose adjust for renal impairment

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust); angioedema history
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; weight gain; edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (late Lyme peripheral neuropathy); concurrent depression

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 wk; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs; blood pressure; serotonin syndrome symptoms

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (Lyme radiculopathy; chronic pain); may also help with insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; titrate by 10-25 mg q1-2wk; target 50-75 mg qHS; max 150 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic risk)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects; sedation; weight

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Short course for acute facial nerve palsy to reduce inflammation and improve recovery; evidence extrapolated from Bell's palsy data; NOT standard of care for Lyme facial palsy and NOT recommended by most experts; discuss with specialist

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (facial palsy adjunctive -- controversial) 60 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 60 mg daily x 5 days, then taper over 5 days; controversial in Lyme -- some experts avoid due to concern for impaired immune clearance of Borrelia; use ONLY with concurrent antibiotics
dosing.orderSentence: Prednisone (facial palsy adjunctive -- controversial) 60 mg PO

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active untreated infection without antibiotics; uncontrolled diabetes

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Eye protection for facial palsy (incomplete eye closure); prevents exposure keratopathy and corneal abrasion

doseOptions.orderSentence: Artificial tears (lubricant eye drops) 1-2 drops TOP

dosing.instructions: Apply lubricant drops q1-2h while awake; use lubricant ointment at bedtime; tape eye closed at night if unable to fully close
dosing.orderSentence: Artificial tears (lubricant eye drops) 1-2 drops TOP

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Corneal integrity; refer ophthalmology if corneal exposure

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting associated with Lyme meningitis or vertigo

dosing.instructions: 4-8 mg IV/PO q6-8h as needed; max 24 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Vertigo associated with cranial nerve VIII involvement (vestibulocochlear nerve)

dosing.instructions: 25 mg PO q6-8h as needed for vertigo; max 100 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Late neuroborreliosis with encephalopathy or peripheral neuropathy; some European guidelines support oral doxycycline for all neuroborreliosis (including meningitis); may be used as step-down therapy after initial IV ceftriaxone

doseOptions.orderSentence: Doxycycline (extended course for late neuroborreliosis) 100 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 100 mg PO BID for 21-28 days (some European protocols use 200 mg BID); IDSA 2020 guidelines suggest oral doxycycline may be equivalent to IV ceftriaxone for neuroborreliosis
dosing.orderSentence: Doxycycline (extended course for late neuroborreliosis) 100 mg PO

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Pregnancy; children <8 years; severe hepatic impairment

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Third-line alternative ONLY when both ceftriaxone and doxycycline are contraindicated; inferior CNS penetration; less well-studied for neuroborreliosis

dosing.instructions: 500 mg PO daily for 14-21 days; limited evidence for CNS disease; use only if no other option

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: QT prolongation; hepatic impairment; concurrent QT-prolonging drugs
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: LFTs; QTc; GI tolerance; hearing (rare ototoxicity)

Second-line/Refractory.item: IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) (for severe Bannwarth syndrome -- rare)
Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe, refractory painful radiculoneuritis (Bannwarth syndrome) not responding to antibiotics and analgesics; limited evidence; case reports only

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) (for severe Bannwarth syndrome -- rare) 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days IV

dosing.instructions: 0.4 g/kg/day IV for 5 days; infuse slowly starting at 0.5 mL/kg/h; premedicate with acetaminophen and diphenhydramine
dosing.orderSentence: IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) (for severe Bannwarth syndrome -- rare) 0.4 g/kg/day x 5 days IV

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: IgA deficiency (anaphylaxis risk); renal impairment; hypercoagulability
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Renal function; infusion reactions; CBC; consider IgA level before first dose

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Lancinating/paroxysmal neuropathic pain in Lyme radiculopathy (similar mechanism to trigeminal neuralgia pain) refractory to gabapentin/pregabalin

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg BID; titrate by 200 mg/day q1wk; target 400-800 mg/day divided BID; max 1200 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: AV block; history of bone marrow suppression; concurrent MAOIs; HLA-B*1502 positive (Asian descent -- screen before starting)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: CBC with differential q2wk x 2 months then q3 months; LFTs; sodium (SIADH); drug level (target 4-12 ug/mL)

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease consultation for treatment optimization, duration guidance, co-infection management, and complex diagnostic interpretation
Neurology consultation for diagnosis confirmation, CSF interpretation, differentiation from MS and other neurologic mimics, and management of neurologic complications
Ophthalmology evaluation for ALL patients with incomplete eye closure from facial palsy to assess corneal exposure risk and recommend eye protection strategy
Audiology evaluation for patients with hearing loss, tinnitus, or vestibular symptoms (cranial nerve VIII involvement) for baseline audiometry
Physical therapy for gait training and balance rehabilitation if ataxia or weakness from myelopathy or peripheral neuropathy
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment and adaptive strategies for patients with hand weakness or fine motor deficits from peripheral neuropathy
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive testing if encephalopathy or cognitive complaints persist after antibiotic treatment to establish baseline and guide rehabilitation
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line and second-line analgesics
Cardiology consultation if ECG shows PR prolongation or AV block (Lyme carditis may coexist with neuroborreliosis and requires separate management)
Social work for discharge planning, home health services coordination, and support resources for prolonged IV antibiotic therapy

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED if: worsening headache, new weakness, vision changes, difficulty breathing, chest pain (Lyme carditis), high fever, or worsening confusion (may indicate disease progression or alternative diagnosis)

Complete the FULL course of antibiotics as prescribed (14-28 days); do NOT stop treatment early even if symptoms improve, as incomplete treatment may lead to persistent or late neurologic complications

Facial palsy from Lyme disease has an excellent prognosis; most patients recover fully within weeks to months with appropriate antibiotic treatment; tape affected eye closed at night and use lubricant drops to protect the cornea

Some symptoms (fatigue, pain, cognitive difficulty) may persist for weeks to months after completing antibiotics (post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome/PTLDS); this does NOT indicate ongoing infection and does NOT require additional antibiotics
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks after completing antibiotics for clinical reassessment; additional follow-up at 3 and 6 months to confirm resolution
Report any new neurologic symptoms (numbness, weakness, cognitive changes, hearing loss, visual changes) between follow-up visits as they may indicate treatment failure or alternative diagnosis
Tick prevention: use DEET-based repellent, wear long sleeves/pants in wooded areas, perform daily tick checks, shower within 2 hours of outdoor activity in endemic areas, and check pets for ticks
Remove attached ticks promptly with fine-tipped tweezers by grasping close to skin and pulling straight out; risk of Lyme transmission is low if tick is removed within 36 hours of attachment
Driving restrictions if significant cognitive impairment, seizures, or visual deficit until cleared by neurology

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Tick bite prevention in endemic areas (Northeast US, upper Midwest, Pacific Northwest): use permethrin-treated clothing, DEET or picaridin repellent, avoid tall grass/leaf litter during peak season (May-September)
Yard maintenance to reduce tick habitat: keep grass short, remove leaf litter, create gravel/wood chip barriers between lawn and wooded areas, consider professional tick treatment
Pet tick prevention with veterinarian-recommended tick control products, as pets can carry ticks into the home environment
Gradual return to physical activity as symptoms improve; rest during acute illness; avoid strenuous exercise until neurologic symptoms have stabilized
Adequate sleep and stress management to support immune recovery during and after treatment
Alcohol avoidance during antibiotic treatment (potential hepatotoxicity with doxycycline; general immune recovery support)
No reinfection immunity: prior Lyme disease does NOT prevent future infections; continue tick prevention measures indefinitely in endemic areas

differential.features: Unilateral facial weakness without other neurologic findings; no tick exposure or erythema migrans; no meningeal symptoms; BILATERAL facial palsy strongly favors Lyme in endemic areas
differential.tests: Lyme serologies (two-tier); CSF analysis (pleocytosis favors Lyme); MRI brain

differential.features: Acute febrile illness with headache, neck stiffness; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis; season (summer/fall for enterovirus); no tick exposure history
differential.tests: BioFire ME panel; viral CSF PCR; Lyme serologies; enterovirus typically has lower CSF protein than Lyme

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; meningitis; CSF pleocytosis; may be clinically indistinguishable; different risk factors (sexual exposure vs. tick exposure)
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL; FTA-ABS; CSF VDRL; Lyme serologies; may coexist

differential.features: Relapsing neurologic deficits; optic neuritis; myelopathy; white matter lesions; younger women; oligoclonal bands positive
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine (periventricular lesions, Dawson fingers); CSF oligoclonal bands; Lyme serologies (must exclude in endemic areas before MS diagnosis)

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (CN VII common); chronic meningitis; granulomatous inflammation; systemic involvement (lungs, skin, eyes)
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar adenopathy); serum/CSF ACE; biopsy; Lyme serologies negative

differential.features: Ascending symmetric weakness; areflexia; cytoalbuminous dissociation (high protein, normal WBC); facial diplegia variant exists
differential.tests: CSF analysis (GBS: high protein, <5 WBC; Lyme meningitis: elevated WBC AND protein); NCS/EMG; anti-ganglioside antibodies; Lyme serologies

differential.features: Subacute chronic meningitis; basilar predominance; cranial neuropathies; very low CSF glucose; very high protein; exposure/travel history
differential.tests: AFB culture; TB PCR (GeneXpert); CSF ADA; chest X-ray; PPD/IGRA; Lyme CSF glucose is NORMAL

differential.features: Bilateral facial palsy (like Lyme); uveoparotid fever (Heerfordt syndrome); erythema nodosum; no tick exposure
differential.tests: Chest imaging; ACE level; biopsy; Lyme serologies negative

differential.features: Chronic meningitis; cranial neuropathies; constitutional symptoms; immunocompromised host
differential.tests: CSF cytology; flow cytometry; brain MRI with contrast; Lyme serologies negative

differential.features: Subacute psychiatric symptoms; seizures; movement disorders; may present with encephalopathy similar to late neuroborreliosis
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (serum + CSF); MRI; EEG; Lyme serologies

differential.features: Summer/fall; mosquito exposure; acute flaccid paralysis; meningoencephalitis; CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: WNV IgM (serum and CSF); Lyme serologies; WNV PCR

evidence.recommendation: IV ceftriaxone 2g daily x 14-28 days for neuroborreliosis with CNS involvement
evidence.source: [Halperin et al. Neurology 2007 (AAN Practice Parameter)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17522387/); [Wormser et al. CID 2006 (IDSA Guidelines)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17029130/)

evidence.recommendation: Oral doxycycline 100 mg BID adequate for isolated facial palsy without CSF abnormalities
evidence.source: [Halperin et al. Neurology 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17522387/); [LjÃ¸stad et al. Eur J Neurol 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18606973/)

evidence.recommendation: Oral doxycycline non-inferior to IV ceftriaxone for European neuroborreliosis
evidence.source: [LjÃ¸stad et al. Eur J Neurol 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18606973/); [Karlsson et al. Neurology 1994](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8035916/)

evidence.recommendation: Two-tier serologic testing (ELISA then Western blot) is standard for Lyme diagnosis
evidence.source: CDC MMWR 2019; Moore et al. CID 2016

evidence.recommendation: CSF Lyme antibody index (intrathecal antibody production) confirms neuroborreliosis
evidence.source: [Halperin et al. Neurology 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17522387/); Blanc et al. CID 2007

evidence.recommendation: CSF pleocytosis (lymphocytic) is the hallmark of active neuroborreliosis
Bilateral facial palsy in endemic area should prompt Lyme testing (present in ~25% of Lyme facial palsy cases)
evidence.source: [Halperin et al. Neurology 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17522387/); [Clark et al. Pediatrics 1985](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3866596/)

evidence.recommendation: Prolonged antibiotic courses (>28 days) provide no additional benefit for post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome (PTLDS)
evidence.source: [Klempner et al. NEJM 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11450676/); [Krupp et al. Neurology 2003](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12821734/); [Berende et al. NEJM 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27028911/)

evidence.recommendation: Co-infection with Babesia and Anaplasma should be considered in endemic areas as it affects clinical presentation and treatment
Lyme carditis with high-degree AV block may require temporary pacemaker; IV ceftriaxone is treatment
evidence.source: Fishe et al. Am J Emerg Med 2015; [Wormser et al. CID 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17029130/)

evidence.recommendation: Facial palsy from Lyme disease has excellent prognosis; >95% recover fully with appropriate antibiotics
evidence.source: [Halperin et al. Neurology 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17522387/); [Bagger-SjÃ¶bÃ¤ck et al. Otol Neurotol 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16015186/)

evidence.recommendation: Modified two-tier testing (MTTT) with two EIA tests improves early sensitivity over standard two-tier
CXCL13 in CSF is an emerging biomarker for active neuroborreliosis
Lyme disease serology (IgG) may remain positive for years after successful treatment; clinical improvement is the primary outcome measure
AAN/IDSA 2020 updated guidelines for prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of Lyme disease

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (cranial nerves, motor, sensory, gait, mental status)
monitoring.action: If declining: reassess diagnosis; repeat imaging; repeat LP; consider treatment failure or alternative diagnosis

monitoring.frequency: Daily inpatient; each outpatient visit for facial palsy patients
monitoring.action: If no improvement by 3 months: repeat Lyme serologies; consider EMG; ophthalmology for corneal protection; neurology reassessment
Persistent fever >48h: reassess diagnosis; evaluate for co-infection (Babesia, Anaplasma); blood cultures

monitoring.frequency: Admission and daily if PR prolonged; repeat if palpitations or syncope
monitoring.action: If PR >300 ms or Mobitz II/complete heart block: cardiology STAT; temporary pacemaker may be needed; IV ceftriaxone continues
Persistent IgG is common and does NOT indicate treatment failure; clinical improvement is the primary measure of treatment response

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then weekly during IV antibiotics
monitoring.action: Dose adjust antibiotics if renal function declines

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then weekly during doxycycline; at completion of therapy
monitoring.action: If transaminases >3x ULN: consider switching antibiotic; evaluate for hepatotoxicity

monitoring.frequency: Baseline, then weekly during antibiotic therapy
monitoring.action: Leukopenia/thrombocytopenia may suggest co-infection (Anaplasma/Ehrlichia); C. difficile if diarrhea

monitoring.frequency: Each visit; daily inpatient if neuropathic pain
monitoring.action: Escalate analgesic therapy per Section 3B; consider pain management referral

monitoring.frequency: Baseline and at follow-up visits; formal testing at 3-6 months if persistent
monitoring.action: If persistent cognitive deficits >6 months after treatment: neuropsychology evaluation; consider PTLDS; supportive care

disposition.criteria: Isolated facial palsy WITHOUT CSF pleocytosis; normal mental status; no meningeal signs; able to take oral medications; reliable follow-up arranged; Lyme serologies sent or positive
Neurologically stable after initial inpatient treatment; PICC line placed; home infusion services arranged; reliable patient with follow-up arranged; no complications of IV therapy

Confirmed or suspected neuroborreliosis with meningitis, encephalopathy, or myelopathy requiring IV antibiotics; bilateral facial palsy (warrants LP and IV treatment); significant radicular pain requiring parenteral pain management; new Lyme carditis with PR prolongation requiring monitoring

Lyme carditis with high-degree AV block requiring temporary pacemaker; severe encephalopathy with altered consciousness (GCS <13); respiratory compromise from myelopathy or ascending weakness; status epilepticus (rare)
Need for temporary pacemaker not available at current facility; need for neurology/infectious disease consultation not available; MRI not available for suspected myelopathy
Late neuroborreliosis with peripheral neuropathy or mild encephalopathy; follow-up after completed inpatient treatment; PTLDS management; oral doxycycline for isolated facial palsy
